address: Mr. Thadeus Siota, Director Climate Change Division, Ministry of Environment, Climate Change, Disaster Management and Meteorology (MECDM), P.O. Box 21, Vavaya Ridge, Honiara, Solomon Islands

bulletin_content1.content: During 2011-2020, the Development finance for projects addressing climate change (both mitigation and adaptation) in Solomon Islands totalled USD 283.73 million (Stockholm Environment Institute, 2023) .

Total $183 million (64.5%) targeted mitigation activities, $98.8 million (34.8%) was targeted at adaptation activities, and $1.93 million (0.68%) targeted both mitigation and adaptation simultaneously.

The disbursement ratio  for development finance to Solomon Islands targeting Climate Change over this period was 42.1%. GCF investment in Solomon Islands amounts to USD 86 million through a project that covers both mitigation and adaptation.

bulletin_content2.content: The largest commitments were $150 million to Energy, $36.4 million to Transport & Storage and $25 million to Water Supply & Sanitation.
SIG has mobilized USD 111 million from Green Climate Fund (GCF
The current portfolio for Solomon Islands is highly concentrated with one hydropower project being managed by the World Bank.

bulletin_content3.content: Technology support and capacity building is critical to achieving high climate ambition.

Solomon Islands has been consistent in mobilizing financial resources and technical assistance from various sources to help offset the burden on economy in combating climate change and managed to obtain these resources to prepare its reports (NCs and BUR), and for the implementation of several linked projects related to climate change that include financial, technical assistance and technology and capacity transfer.
The Solomon Islands will start on its Technology Needs Assessment (TNA) process in 2020 (USD 295,650 requested from GEF).

bulletin_content4.content: Received training and capacity building for the preparation of the TNC and FBUR from International consultants as a part of the TNC and FBUR project.

Received several other training and capacity building under Bilateral, Multilateral and Regional programs and projects. Example:  CBIT Project for the Solomon Islands, Strengthening capacity in the agriculture and land-use as well as energy sectors.

climate_change_division_content1: The Climate Change Division aims to send a strong message to Solomon Islanders, the global community, and the country’s donor partners on the high level of importance the Government places on the issue of climate change. The mandate and operations of the division include; close monitoring of the extent to which Solomon Islands is vulnerable to the effects of climate change, playing a leading role in mobilizing resources for adaptation and mitigation initiatives, conducting relevant and priority research and information dissemination activities, seek resources to support national programs to mitigate the causes of climate change and be the country’s lead agency in addressing Solomon Islands’ obligations as a Party to the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change (UNFCCC) and Solomon Islands’ commitment to the Pacific Islands Climate Change Framework.
climate_change_division_content2:
Vision of CCD: A resilient, secure, and sustainable Solomon Islands responding to climate change.

Mission Statement: To enhance adaptation, disaster risk reduction, and mitigation capacity throughout the Solomon Islands that contributes to increased resilience and achievement of sustainable development goals.

Functions and Responsibility:

• To oversee the implementation of and be the focal point for climate

change projects.

• To conduct assessments of the vulnerability of the Solomon Islands to climate change.

• To look at ways that Solomon Islanders can cope with the impact of climate change adaptation to climate change.

• To represent the Solomon Islands Government and its people at international climate change meetings and negotiations.

• To conduct awareness and education Programmes for the public in schools and communities and through media and face-to-face workshops.
climate_change_division_content3:
2. SI's long-term climate change goals and policy directive for climate change mitigation, adaptation, and long-term strategy

• Solomon Islands is committed to ambitious long-term climate change goals, aiming to become a negative carbon emitter.

• The Nationally Determined Contribution (NDC) outlines targets for emission reductions, with commitments to reduce emissions by 14% by 2025 and by 33% by 2030 compared to 2015 levels, with potential further reductions with international assistance.

• Mitigation efforts are aligned with national strategies and policies, including the National Development Strategy 2016-2035, the Climate Change Policy 2012-2017, and the National Energy Policy 2014.

• Key mitigation efforts include investments in renewable energy, such as solar and hydropower projects, with potential opportunities in sectors like forestry and transport.

• Adaptation programs are aligned with national priorities and often externally funded, highlighting the need for mainstreaming climate change adaptation into sectoral plans and programs to address resource limitations.Top of Form


3. Support (Financial, Technology Transfer, and Capacity Building) Requirements

• Continued financial support is required to finance climate change projects in Solomon Islands.

• Funding is needed for both mitigation and adaptation activities.

• Timely disbursement of funds is essential to accelerate progress in addressing climate change challenges.

• Technical assistance and capacity building are crucial for enhancing climate ambition.

• Ongoing support is required for technology transfer and capacity-building initiatives.

• Access to financial resources, technology, and capacity-building support is essential for the effective implementation of climate mitigation and adaptation measures.

• Resources are needed to support the Technology Needs Assessment (TNA) process to identify priority sectors and technologies.

• Additional funding is required to strengthen institutional and technical capacity for compliance with international climate agreements.

• Further training and capacity-building programs are needed to enhance expertise in preparing climate change reports and implementing mitigation and adaptation measures.

• Continued support is required for initiatives such as the Capacity-building Initiative for Transparency (CBIT) to strengthen technical and institutional capacities.

cross_cutting_table.project_title: Integrated Economic Development and Community Resilience Project
Integrated Forest Management in the Solomon Islands

Strengthening capacity in the agriculture and land-use as well as energy sectors in Solomon Islands for enhanced transparency in implementation and monitoring of Solomon Island’s Nationally Determined Contribution (NDC)

description_1:
What is MRV?


• Monitoring (M) - Applies to both, efforts to address climate change and impacts of these efforts. It occurs at the national level and refers to measuring the level of GHG emissions (Inventory), mitigation/adaptation actions and their impacts, and the support (finance) needed and received.


• Reporting (R) - National communications and BURs/BTRs, where Parties report on their actions to address climate change in their national communications (now NDCs as well);


• Verification (V) – Through domestic and international consultation and analysis (ICA).


Integrated Monitoring, Reporting and Verification ( iMRV) Tool for Climate Actions (Version 1.0)


The Integrated Monitoring, Reporting, and Verification (iMRV) system and database (or iMRV Tool-Version 1.0) for Climate Actions and Nationally Determined Contribution (NDC) has been developed to implement the Paris Agreement and Enhance Transparency Framework (ETF) requirements effectively and efficiently. The Solomon Islands iMRV Tool transparently communicates climate actions (mitigation and adaptation), strategies, programs, climate finance, and SDG impacts, to the domestic and international stakeholders, development partners, and the international community.


The iMRV Tool provides an overarching structure, approach, and methodology for:


National GHG Inventory: The National GHG inventory is typically an annual inventory of anthropogenic emissions by sources and removals by sinks of greenhouse gases (GHGs) not controlled by the Montreal Protocol. Direct GHG emissions of gases: Carbon dioxide (CO2), Methane (CH4), Nitrous oxide (N2O), Oxides of nitrogen (NOx), Carbon monoxide (CO), Non-methane volatile organic compounds (NMVOC)and Sulphur dioxide (SO2) from different sectors like Energy, Industrial Processes and Product Use (IPPU), Agriculture, Forestry and Other Land Use (AFOLU) and Waste. The iMRV Tool also includes implied emission factors, activity data, and supplementary information.


Mitigation Action Tracking: The Mitigation Action Tracking Module focuses on both project implementation and operation phases. The bottom-up approach has been applied for a comprehensive and integrated system.


Adaptation Action and Priorities Tracking: The Adaptation Action Module includes monitoring and tracking of adaptation actions and priories. This module follows the bottom approach and methodology for tracking qualitative and quantitative impacts on Disaster (Drought and Flood) Risk Management, Food and Nutrition Security, Water and the Blue Economy, Forestry, Wildlife and Tourism, Health, Sanitation and Human Settlement, Manufacturing, Energy and Transport along with impact on Gender and other Vulnerable population, with periodicity of monitoring.


Climate Finance: This has given due importance to international and domestic financial flow for Climate Change (mitigation and adaptation), also defined under the Paris Agreement and ETF. The aspect of the climate finance module includes tracking, monitoring, and reporting of the international finance received, disbursement of the international and domestic financial flow towards the implementation of NDC commitment and achieving climate change objectives.


Co-benefits (SDGs and Gender Impact): The SDG Module of the iMRV Tool includes monitoring and progress tracking of the SDG impact of climate actions. The SDG module is based on the UNDP's Climate Action Impact (CAIT) methodology.

﻿
